Understate: The claim understates the number of deaths attributed to Covid-19 by stating that the CDC cut the national Covid-19 death toll by 94 percent. The expert's verdict explains that the smaller number of death certificates that only cited Covid-19 as a cause may not have included complications or other serious illnesses related to the disease.
Falters at times: The claim falters by not providing enough detail or context about the death certificates and the information they contain. It fails to acknowledge that deaths related to Covid-19 may also include other serious illnesses and complications.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support to back up its assertion that the CDC cut the national Covid-19 death toll by 94 percent. The expert's verdict provides information that contradicts this claim and explains the limitations of the data.
Problematic assumption: The claim makes a problematic assumption that the number of deaths attributed solely to Covid-19 is the only relevant measure of the impact of the disease. The expert's verdict highlights the importance of considering complications and other serious illnesses related to Covid-19 in determining the true impact.
Exist alternative explanation: The claim does not consider alternative explanations for the data presented. The expert's verdict explains that the smaller number of death certificates may not have included all relevant information and that deaths related to Covid-19 may also include other serious illnesses.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that deaths related to Covid-19 may include other serious illnesses and complications. The expert's verdict provides evidence that supports this fact.
Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates the impact of the CDC's actions by stating that the death toll was cut by 94 percent. The expert's verdict provides a more nuanced explanation of the data and its limitations.
